materials: Bones of the sea monster Coinchenn

linguistic.originalScript: Old Irish: G√°e Bolga / G√°e Bulga

etymology.derivation: From Old Irish g√°e (spear, javelin) + bolga (of bags/bellies, from bolg = bag, belly). Proto-Celtic *gaisos (spear). Etymology debated: either 'belly-spear' (enters belly, creates barbs) or from Belgae tribal name. Creates 30 barbs upon entry
etymology.meaning: Spear of Mortal Pain, Belly-spear, Lightning-spear

originPoint.name: Ireland/Alba (Ulster Cycle tradition)
originPoint.description: Featured in Ulster Cycle. Given to C√∫ Chulainn by Sc√°thach in Alba (Scotland). Made from sea monster bones. Reflects Irish warrior tradition and tragic hero narrative

shortDescription: Legendary barbed spear of Cu Chulainn that creates thirty barbs upon entering the body
name: Gae Bulg

mythologyContexts.usage: Primary weapon of Cu Chulainn, used only in dire circumstances due to its lethal nature. Most famously used to kill his foster-brother Ferdiad during the Cattle Raid of Cooley

textReferences.context: Cu Chulainn uses the Gae Bulg to kill his foster-brother Ferdiad in single combat
textReferences.passage: The Combat of Ferdiad and Cu Chulainn

textReferences.context: The spear is used against Cu Chulainn himself by Lugaid

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Represents the terrible cost of war and the tragedy of conflict between brothers. The weapon's unstoppable nature symbolizes fate and the inescapability of destiny once certain paths are chosen.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: The Gae Bulg is one of the most famous weapons in Irish mythology, representing the ultimate martial prowess but also the sorrow of fratricide and the heavy burden of the warrior's path.

modernLegacy.culturalImpact: The Gae Bulg is one of the most famous weapons in Irish mythology, representing the ultimate martial prowess but also the sorrow of fratricide and the heavy burden of the warrior's path.

worshipPractices: Primary weapon of Cu Chulainn, used only in dire circumstances due to its lethal nature. Most famously used to kill his foster-brother Ferdiad during the Cattle Raid of Cooley

temporal.timelinePosition: La T√®ne period (450-1 BCE) warrior tradition, Roman Celtic period (1-400 CE) Ulster Cycle oral tradition, Early Medieval Ireland (400-800 CE) literary codification
temporal.culturalPeriod: Iron Age Celtic warrior culture through Early Medieval Irish literature

firstAttestation.source: T√°in B√≥ C√∫ailnge and Ulster Cycle
firstAttestation.description: Featured prominently in T√°in B√≥ C√∫ailnge (Cattle Raid of Cooley) and Aided Chon Culainn. Most famous for killing Ferdiad. Ulster Cycle oral tradition predates manuscripts

longDescription: The Gae Bulg (Irish: spear of mortal pain/death) is the legendary weapon of the Irish hero Cu Chulainn. Crafted from the bones of a sea monster and given to Cu Chulainn by his martial arts teacher Scathach, this fearsome spear was thrown with the foot and created thirty barbs upon penetrating the victim's body, making it impossible to remove without killing the victim. It could only be removed by cutting away the flesh around it.
